column4: what's the better way to clean a compiled source installation?
No, chaddy's suggestions are the convention
For debian/Ubuntu packages, use "fakeroot debian/rules clean"
what could have possibly gone wrong if the package doesn't go away after a make clean?
get cleaned.. for example.. not that is the most important issue, but the menu links are still there
OH! You don't mean the source code at all! You mean the installed binary package?
but a package installed by compiling its source
What package / application is it you're working with?
Usually, the source will have a target to uninstall: "sudo make uninstall"
If you're not sure, open the source-code's Makefile and look for any target name that suggests it uninstalls the package
the source from which i configured and "made" the package is gone.. downloaded it again.. so I should re-./configure it, right?
I'd guess so, to recreate the Makefile, yes, then you an look for an uninstall target
worked.. must've done something wrong first time.. ty guys
great, glad you got it sorted :)
